title: What is something that was acceptable in the past but would be considered unacceptable today? - Quora

response.answer_text: Popular songs sung by adult men about their love for teenage girls, a dissonance in values highlighted by this SNL sketch:  It’s sort of forgotten today that, in the years closer to the mid-20th century, it was not uncommon for young women to marry before they’d even reached 20, even more so in the areas of the country where rock ’n’ roll got its start (Not that this was unique to rock’n’roll, as the huge success Maurice Chevalier had with “Thank Heaven for Little Girls”, a song that in its original context sounds unimaginably creepy now). I also think that as a consequence of the war, a lot of older veterans who’d had to put off marriage took younger brides, often from overseas, which tended to make the practice more palatable at home where it might not otherwise have been. But we have left those times behind for an era in which women are presumed as likely as men to be planning on college and starting a career afterwards at that time of their lives. So, proclaiming this sort of ephebophilic love in song no longer seems as romantic as it might have even as late as Benny Mardones’ “Into the Night” in 1980. In fact, it was around that time that pop music began seriously to reflect this change. First there was the Cars’ biggest hit up to that point, “Let’s Go”, in which the singer, like Doug Fieger in the Knack’s even bigger contemporary hit “My Sharona”, sings of his love for a 17-year-old girl. However, in the Cars’ song, he is respectful of her desire not to lose her virginity until the right guy or time comes along. The next year the Police released that song of our moment (for an entirely different reason) “Don’t Stand So Close to Me”, about an affair between a young schoolteacher and a female student “half his age” (Sting had been a student teacher in the mid-1970s before joining the Police, and said he was inspired by the obvious crushes his female students had on him (not hard to imagine from pictures of him at that time) and some of the other younger men in the school, and while he never had an affair with one of them as is sometimes said to be the basis of the song he did admit he felt the same reciprocal attraction)). The song clearly suggests, from the title on down, that this is not something either of them should do, and shows both of them suffering negative social consequences before they even consummate the affair (what Sting says happens in the teacher’s “warm and dry” car after the end of the song). Later that year Steely Dan also released “Hey Nineteen”, which doesn’t creep anyone out as much today because 19 is still sort of acceptable, but most importantly because the entire song is built around the 30ish singer realizing that he and “Nineteen” have “nothing in common” due to the age difference other than a shared interest in getting drunk and high. Yes, the Stray Cats still had a huge hit a little later on with “Sexy and 17”, but I think that’s about the last one (and sort of excused by being in that deliberately retro rockabilly style).
